Project Description  As part of the sector-wide management of the health sector, the 
Project  will  support  the  implementation  of  the  Health  Sector 
Strategic  Plan  of  the  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH).  The  Project  is 
cofinanced by the Department for International Development of the 
United Kingdom (DFID) and International Development Association 
(IDA). The Project will focus on providing basic health services to 
the poor and disadvantaged, including ethnic minorities, women, 
and  children,  in  21  provinces.  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
financing  will  cover  nine  provinces  and  will  improve  access  to 
quality health services by upgrading commune health centers and 
district referral hospitals and enhancing the skills of health care 
service providers. The Project will support contracting of health 
services  to  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  in  11  poor 
operational  districts.  The  Project  will  also  support  public  health 
priorities, including national programs for tuberculosis (TB), malaria, 
HIV/AIDS, nutrition, and safe motherhood. The Project emphasizes 
building the capacity of MOH for planning, financing, and managing 
health services. 
   
Rationale  Health indicators in Cambodia are among the most adverse in the 
region. Health infrastructure needs significant strengthening. The 
quality of health services in public and private sectors is poor. 
Skills of health care providers need to be upgraded. Although 
considerable progress has been made in the last 5 years, further 
support and consolidation are required to improve access and 
utilization  of  health  services,  especially  by  the  poor  and 
disadvantaged.  The  capacity  of  MOH  to  plan,  finance,  and 
manage  health  services  remains  weak  and  needs  to  be 
strengthened.

iv   
Objectives   The objectives of the Project are to (i) increase the institutional 
capacity to plan, finance, and manage the health sector in line 
with  the  Health  Sector  Strategic  Plan;  (ii)  develop  affordable, 
good-quality,  basic  curative  and  preventive  health  services, 
especially  for  women,  the  poor,  and  the  disadvantaged;  (iii) 
increase the utilization of health services, especially by women and 
the poor; and (iv) control and mitigate the effects of infectious 
disease epidemics and of malnutrition, with emphasis on the poor. 
 
The Project will have three components: (i) improved delivery of 
health services, (ii) support to priority public health programs, and 
(iii) strengthening of institutional capacity.

Project Benefits and  ADB financing of the Project will cover more than 5 million people 
Beneficiaries  (40%  of  the  total  population),  who  will  benefit  from  improved 
availability  and  quality  of  health  services.  In  particular,  project 
interventions will improve health care coverage for the rural poor, 
who currently have very limited access to even the most basic 
health services. An estimated 4.6 million beneficiaries will come 
from  the  rural  population,  accounting  for  92%  of  total 
beneficiaries. The Project will improve access to quality health 
service  for  2.5  million  women,  through  strengthened  safe-
motherhood  services  and  improved  antenatal  care  and 
emergency obstetric facilities. The Project will also have a major 
impact on improving the health status of ethnic minorities in the 
provinces of Mondol Kiri and Rattanak Kiri, which are among the 
poorest in the country. The Project will benefit about 2 million poor 
people. The poor, who make up 36% of the population in the 
project area, capture more than 47% of the project benefits. 
 
Using  very  conservative  assumptions,  the  Project  has  an 
economic internal rate of return of 17–27%. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  project  interventions  involve  almost  no  technical  risk. 
However, the implementation of a substantial and jointly financed 
Project poses a serious challenge to the Government’s capacity to 
absorb and properly utilize available resources. This risk is being 
minimized in the Project through strong capacity-building support, 
largely  funded  by  DFID  grants,  and  provision  of  consulting 
services to support procurement and disbursement.  
 
Another  challenge  for  the  Government  will  be  to  ensure  the 
sustainability  of  the  facilities  constructed  and  the  services 
introduced,  especially  after  the  end  of  the  Project.  To  ensure 
proper maintenance of health facilities and equipment, the Project 
will help MOH prepare maintenance plans and manuals for each 
health facility and develop capacity for regular maintenance.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan to the Kingdom of Cambodia for the Health Sector Support Project,1 and (ii) proposed 
administration by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of a grant for the Project to be provided 
by the Government of the United Kingdom. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Sector Performance 
2.  From extremely low levels only 10 years ago, the Cambodian private and public sector 
health system has developed rapidly. The achievements of the Ministry of Health (MOH) during 
this brief period have been encouraging. MOH has developed a national health policy that 
includes major financial reforms (e.g., budgetary reforms, introduction of user fees) and a 
national system of primary health care coverage. Polio has been eradicated. MOH has also 
made substantial progress in other critical areas of public health, including HIV/AIDS prevention 
and  in  the  introduction  of  modern  birth-spacing  methods.  Most  commendably,  MOH  has 
remained open to change and has piloted several innovative approaches for increasing the 
coverage  and  quality  of  health  services,  including  contracting  of  health  services  to 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and use of equity funds to support the poor. 
 
3.  Notwithstanding  the  encouraging  progress  in  the  last  decade,  health  indicators  in 
Cambodia are still among the worst in the Asia and Pacific region. Average life expectancy at 
birth is estimated at only 56.4 years—54.4 years for men and 58.3 years for women. The infant 
mortality rate is estimated to be 95 per 1,000 live births, while the mortality rate under the age of 
5 is 124, and the maternal mortality ratio is 437 per 100,000 live births (Cambodia Demographic 
and Health Survey 2000). Rates of malnutrition are the second highest in Southeast Asia, with 
an estimated 56% of children under 5 affected by chronic malnutrition. 
 
4.  The country's progress toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) 
has been slow. Infant and child mortality rates appear to have increased in the 1990s. The 
targets for infant and under-5 mortality rates for 2015 are 42 and 59, respectively, or half the 
present levels. Given the stagnant and, in fact, slightly increasing trends in these rates in the 
past few years, the achievement of the MDGs will be difficult unless reproductive and child 
health services expand considerably. Similarly, the maternal mortality ratio remains high and is 
not falling as rapidly as required to achieve the target of 150 by 2015. Achieving the goals of 
ensuring universal access to reproductive health services and halting and reversing the spread 
of communicable diseases, including HIV/AIDS, malaria, and tuberculosis (TB), will also need 
accelerated efforts. 
 
B.  Key Problems and Opportunities 
5.  The health sector faces considerable challenges in the short and medium term. In 
particular, the following critical issues need to be addressed to expand and sustain future 
progress in health: 
 
6.  Access, Utilization, and Health Benefits by the Poor. This is the major challenge for 
the sector.  In the past 5 years, a large number of health facilities have been improved; major

initiatives in national health programs have been undertaken; and service capacities have been 
considerably expanded. However, the MOH Health Coverage Plan, which identifies all health 
facilities required to provide adequate health service coverage in the country, is only 80% 
implemented. Many poor communes and districts still lack properly equipped health facilities of 
acceptable quality. 
 
7.  Poor Cambodians have not proportionally benefited from health service improvements. 
In 1998, only 27% of poor children were fully vaccinated compared to 52% of nonpoor children. 
Individuals from the wealthiest quintile are also more than twice as likely to be admitted to a 
hospital as compared to those from the poorest quintile, despite the fact that the poor have 
worse  health.  Health  care  expenses  are  a  major  cause  of  distress  sales,  indebtedness, 
landlessness, and poverty. Poor people’s access to health services is constrained by both 
supply and demand side factors. The lack of physical infrastructure in poor areas, lack of 
resources to pay for health services, and poor knowledge about the need and availability of 
public health services limit poor people’s utilization of health services. Around 21% of the 
poorest quintile have to travel more than 5 kilometers to seek basic health services, compared 
to 14% of the richest quintile. The quality of services in poor areas is significantly worse than in 
nonpoor areas.  
 
8.  MOH instituted user charges for health services in 1996 through the Health Finance 
Charter (HFC) in response to the unpredictable informal fees that were being charged in most 
MOH facilities and that had contributed to a marked shift from public to private providers. HFC 
authorized MOH facilities to charge user fees and established a formula for allocating the 
resulting revenue. HFC exempted the poor from paying user charges. However, studies show 
that the cost of health services for the poor remains high. User fees, including exemptions for 
the poor, appear to have worked well at health centers but not at hospitals, where fees are 
considerably higher. Hospitals have been reluctant to publicize their fee structures. Even in 
hospitals where user fees have been regularized and are carefully monitored, the exemption 
system is not operating effectively and facilities do not have adequate incentives to treat the 
poor. 
 
9.  The quality of health services needs improvement. Many rural MOH facilities have staff 
shortages, which limit access to general and specialized health services. Remote health centers 
are seriously understaffed, in midwifery and reproductive health services. A large proportion of 
health providers lack the necessary curative and preventive skills to provide effective health 
care. The referral system between health centers and hospitals is poorly developed. 
 
10.  The Government piloted the contracting of health services to NGOs under the Basic 
Health  Services  Project  (BHSP).2  The  results3 of the pilot show that contracting of health 
services to NGOs can effectively improve access and utilization of health services in rural areas 
in a short time, especially for the poor. This represents an important viable alternative to public 
provision of health services, particularly in remote areas.  
 
11.  Communicable  Diseases.  Communicable  diseases  remain  the  main  causes  of 
mortality and morbidity. The rural poor, particularly young children and women of reproductive 
age, are the most vulnerable. TB and malaria are the major causes of morbidity and mortality for 
adults. Cambodia is ranked as a high-burden country for TB (two thirds of the population, or 8

quarters of the entire burden of disease is preventable through low-cost interventions. 
 
12.  Lack  of  Qualified  Human  Resources.  The  lack  of  trained  health  care  providers 
remains the key constraint in improving the performance of public health providers and provision 
of services to the poor. Public providers will continue to be important sources of health services 
in both public and private sectors. At the same time, the capacity of government resources to 
finance these providers through the budget will continue to be severely constrained. Appropriate 
personnel policies and incentive structures need to be introduced to rectify the human resource 
imbalance between rural and urban areas. The MOH Health Sector Strategic Plan 2003-2007 
(Strategic Plan) identifies human resource development as one of the six key areas of work. 
The strategy calls for enhancing the skills of the workforce through quality education, expanding 
the number and skills of midwives, and strengthening workforce planning and management to 
reduce maldistribution and ensure efficient use of human resources. 
 
13.  Limited Institutional Capacity. Poor capacity to effectively plan, manage, and finance 
the health sector at all levels significantly contributes to the poor performance of basic curative 
and preventive services. Improving institutional capacity is critical for ensuring better use of 
health services and increased benefits to the population, particularly the poor. As in other 
sectors in the country, low salaries of civil servants and health care providers imply that the key 
personnel in MOH have to look for other sources of income and are often not available full-time 
to  fulfill  their  responsibilities.  Establishing  an  effective  incentive  and  salary  structure  is  a 
prerequisite for strengthening the capacity of MOH.  
 
14.  Several international agencies are supporting the reconstruction and development of the 
health sector (Appendix 2). Official development assistance accounts for more than half of the 
consolidated  public  funding  to  the  sector.  Major  partners  include  ADB,  Department  for 
International  Development  (DFID),  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development 
(USAID), Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA), Japan International Cooperation 
Agency (JICA), Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), German Agency for 
Technical Cooperation (GTZ), World Bank, World Health Organization (WHO), and other United 
Nations (UN) agencies. International support—chiefly investment for developing infrastructure, 
and technical assistance (TA) for developing policies and processes—has played a critical role 
in developing the sector.  
 
15.  Within  the  context  of  the  national  development  strategy,  MOH  has  developed  the 
Strategic Plan and Medium-Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF). To achieve the overall goal 
of  improving  health  status  and  reducing  poverty,  the  Strategic  Plan  identifies  eight  core 
strategies  in  the  six  priority  areas:  health  service  delivery,  behavior  change,  quality 
improvement, human resource development, health financing, and institutional development 
(Appendix 3). This plan will form the basis for planning and financing health services and 
directing international support during 2003-2007. The Project—jointly financed by ADB, DFID, 
and the International Development Association of the World Bank Group (IDA)—will directly 
support the Strategic Plan and fill funding gaps identified in MTEF. The Project is also in line 
with ADB’s operational strategy in Cambodia, which emphasizes human resource development 
as one of three pillars and identifies the health sector as one of the key sectors.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objectives 
16.  The Project will improve health status, especially of women, children, and the poor, in 
targeted regions of Cambodia. Specifically, the Project aims to 
 
(i)  increase the institutional capacity to plan, finance, and manage the health sector 
in line with the Health Sector Strategic Plan; 
 
(ii)  develop affordable, quality, basic curative and preventive health services for the 
population, especially for women, the poor, and the disadvantaged; 
 
(iii)  increase the utilization of health services, especially by women and the poor; and 
 
(iv)  control and mitigate the effects of infectious epidemics and of malnutrition with 
emphasis on the poor and disadvantaged.  
 
B.  Scope 
17.  Project Area. The Project will help strengthen health services in 21 provinces, support 
national-level activities for communicable disease control, and strengthen the capacity of MOH. 
ADB financing will help to improve services in nine provinces—Kompong Cham, Kompong 
Chhnang, Koh Kong, Mondol Kiri, Prey Veng, Rattanak Kiri, Krong Prean Sihanouk, Svay 
Rieng, and Takeo. Of these, five (Kompong Cham, Kompong Chhnang, Prey Veng, Svay Rieng, 
and Takeo) were covered under BHSP and will require only some supplementary investments. 
The additional provinces were selected based on their incidence of poverty and prevalence of 
communicable  diseases.  Selection  criteria  and  health  sector-related  information  about  the 
provinces covered by ADB is in Appendix 4. ADB financing will also cover selected regional and 
central  MOH  activities.  IDA  financing  will  cover  12  provinces,  national-level  communicable 
disease control, and other selected MOH activities. A DFID grant will mostly support national-
level  capacity  building,  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E),  safe-motherhood  activities, 
approaches for improving access of the poor to health services, and contracting of health 
services to NGOs. A significant part of the DFID grant will be channeled through ADB or IDA. 
 
18.  The Project will be implemented under the overall framework defined in the Strategic 
Plan. Financing needs will inevitably change over the project period as other development 
partners  commit  their  funding.  Therefore,  proposed  investments  will  be  reviewed  annually 
together with the Government and other partners to confirm the need for planned investments. 
As part of the Strategic Plan, MOH together with all development partners and civil society will 
undertake an annual sector review before 31 May every year. These agencies and groups will 
review sector performance and project progress, and agree upon a 3-year rolling plan, including 
a detailed operational plan for the subsequent year (Appendix 5). 
 
19.  The Project has three components. The project design was based on an extensive 
health sector review and social assessment, and was developed with active participation of 
NGOs, communities, international agencies working in the health sector and the Government. 
 
1.  Improved Delivery of Health Services 
 
20.  This component focuses on improving health service quality, utilization, and access, 
especially for the poor, women, and ethnic minorities in 21 project provinces. ADB will finance

provinces. Specifically, financing will involve  (i) construction and renovation of health centers 
and health posts, and renovation of referral hospitals; (ii) provision of medical and auxiliary 
equipment to health centers and referral hospitals; (iii) training in the minimum package of 
activities (MPA) and complementary package of activities (CPA);4 (iv) provision of alternative

a.  Building and Civil Works 
 
21.   Under  this  subcomponent,  new  and  renovated  facilities  (including  health  centers, 
referral hospitals, operational district offices and drugstores) will be developed to meet the 
standards of MPA and CPA services according to the Health Coverage Plan (HCP). It outlines 
the health facilities required to provide adequate access to health services. Priority will be given 
to  health  facilities  in  remote  and  poor  areas.  The  Project  will  also  support  a  review  and 
necessary revision of HCP to account for changes in demographics, road infrastructure, and the 
health system since its preparation in 1995.  
 
22.  The Project will give priority to health centers, which are the first point of access to basic 
health care. Based on HCP, the Project will also support smaller health posts in sparsely 
populated mountainous areas inhabited by ethnic minorities. ADB will finance the construction 
or renovation of 128 health centers and 9 health posts in the nine target provinces. Referral 
hospitals are the first link to provide curative health services to the population and play a major 
role in helping women with complicated deliveries. ADB will finance the renovation of 14 referral 
hospitals and 10 emergency facilities in referral hospitals across the nine provinces. In these 
hospitals, special emphasis will be given to safe-motherhood facilities. The civil works program, 
when completed, will meet HCP standards and ensure that all health centers can adequately 
provide MPA services, and all referral hospitals, CPA services. 
 
23.  Designs  of  health  facilities  under  the  Project  will  conform  to  MOH  guidelines.  The 
designs will provide adequate visual and auditory privacy to the patients and also toilets for 
women  and  men.  The  facilities  will  be  simple  and  will  use  indigenous  materials  for  easy 
maintenance.  All  facilities  will  have  adequate  medical  waste  disposal  units.  A  facilities 
maintenance plan will also be developed. The Project will support the implementation of the 
maintenance plan. 
 
b.  Medical and Auxiliary Equipment 
 
24.  The Project will help provide and maintain medical equipment in new and renovated 
health centers to provide MPA, and in renovated referral hospitals to provide CPA. Service 
quality will also be improved by providing MPA kits to train staff trainers and health center 
personnel. As with civil works, this subcomponent will aim to complete HCP and meet the 
requirements for providing MPA and CPA services. 
 
25.  MOH has developed a list of equipment required to deliver MPA services in health 
centers. The Project will support the provision of MPA kits, including obstetric equipment, to 
each new health center. MOH is finalizing CPA service guidelines and equipment lists. Three

included and then help provide the kits (including surgical and obstetric equipment) to renovated 
referral hospitals to fill the shortage of functional equipment and enable the hospitals to deliver 
appropriate CPA. Auxiliary equipment—generators and x-ray machines—will be provided to 
renovated referral hospitals, and ambulances to five major referral hospitals. 
 
26.  The capacity for equipment maintenance in the Hospital Services Department will be 
strengthened through TA and training. Procurement and supply of equipment will be closely 
coordinated with civil works. The Project will ensure that health personnel are trained to use and 
maintain the equipment and that operational manuals are supplied in the Khmer language. The 
Government will provide necessary funds to maintain the equipment. 
 
c.  Training of Health Service Providers 
 
27.  The Project will take a comprehensive approach to the training of health center and 
referral  hospital  staff  to  deliver  MPA  and  CPA  services.  Training  quality,  relevance,  and 
efficiency will be addressed; the MOH continuing education system strengthened; and priority 
MPA and CPA training courses implemented. Subcomponent activities will include (i) training of 
(a) 70 provincial and 204 district trainers in teaching methods and curriculum content; (b) 100 
provincial continuing education coordinators in management; and (c) 8,279 health center staff 
and 4,550 referral hospital staff in the nine target provinces; and (ii) follow-up of trainees. 
Workers in the most remote areas will be trained to directly benefit ethnic minority populations 
and to impart reproductive health skills. Equal training opportunities will be given to women and 
ethnic minorities, especially those working in very remote areas. 
 
28.  MOH has developed 13 MPA training modules under the ADB-supported Basic Skills 
Project5 and commenced a comprehensive program of in-service training to enable health 
center staff to deliver these services. The Project will support training of health center staff in the 
target provinces in the priority MPA modules, including child health, reproductive health, health 
promotion, and infection control. Training will be based on regular training-needs assessments 
and will reflect priorities identified in the Strategic Plan. Training will be supported by the 
development  or  review  of  training  curricula  where  needed.  The  Project  will  also  seek  to 
strengthen systems to monitor and evaluate training, quality control, and accreditation.  
 
d.  Contracting of Services to NGOs 
 
29.  An operations research pilot of contracting health services to NGOs was found to be 
very efficient, equitable, and cost-effective in BHSP (Appendix 6). Building on the experience of 
the  pilot  study,  provision  of  health  services  will  be  contracted  to  NGOs  in  11  operational 
districts,  selected  for  their  poverty  levels,  weak  capacity  in  service  delivery,  poor  access, 
remoteness, and ethnic minority concentration. ADB and DFID will jointly finance the contracting 
of services in 10 operational districts, while IDA will support contracting in 1. This support will 
ensure quality services in poor operational districts covering about 1.8 million people, including 
800,000 poor, and build MOH capacity to manage and monitor NGO contracts.

e.  Supplies and Drugs 
 
33.  The Project will finance drugs and supplies required to provide MPA. ADB will finance 
MPA start-up drug kits to new health centers in the target provinces. As women and children 
constitute the vast majority of patients at the health centers, this support will provide more-than-
proportionate benefits to this population. MPA start-up drug kits will be provided through the 
Central Medical Store (CMS). The MPA start-up drug kits contain a 6-month supply of basic 
drugs and contraceptives, based on average consumption figures. These kits will ensure that 
facilities become operational immediately upon opening and allow them to determine their 
consumption and join the routine 3-month ordering cycle through CMS. 
 
34.  IDA funding for this subcomponent will finance activities to strengthen procurement, 
storage, and testing of drugs and pharmaceuticals. In particular, the Project will help establish a 
central drug procurement unit, strengthen the Food and Drug Department, and upgrade the 
National Drug Quality Control Laboratory. IDA will finance a pilot study on using revolving funds 
for essential drugs. 
 
2.  Support to Programs Addressing Public Health Priority  
 
35.  The  Project  will  finance  national  programs  to  control  and  prevent  communicable 
diseases, including HIV/AIDS, malaria, and TB. The Project will also support important public 
health activities, including safe motherhood, immunization, and nutrition. This component will fill 
critical financing gaps in management and inputs for public health priority programs.

36.  The proposed investments will be closely coordinated with the investments by other 
international agencies, including the Global Fund for AIDS, TB and Malaria (GFATM); DFID; 
USAID; and UN agencies. A significant amount of support for priority public health programs is 
already committed by several agencies. ADB is providing substantial financing for prevention

3.  Strengthening Institutional Capacity  
 
37.  The Project will help strengthen institutional capacity in management, planning, and 
evaluation at the national, provincial, and district levels. The support will improve the capacity of 
MOH to undertake health sector reforms in accordance with the Strategic Plan, including the 
capacity for evidence-based planning, health service management and financing, and M&E. 
This component will be closely coordinated with other development partners, especially WHO. 
ADB financing under this component will support (i) strengthening of management capacity and 
supervision at the provincial and district levels in the nine target provinces, (ii) capacity for 
workforce planning and management in MOH, (iii) training capacity at regional and national 
levels, and (iv) M&E. 
 
a.  Health Service Planning and Management Capacity Strengthening 
 
38.  ADB will finance the training of 123 provincial, district, and referral hospital managers in 
the nine target provinces in health service management, including planning, monitoring, and 
evaluation.  Equal  opportunities  will  be  given  to  competent  women  and  ethnic  minority 
managers. The Project will also support and expand the MOH program of supervision, and 
finance the development of annual provincial and district plans. Community participation in 
health service management will be supported through health center committees that equally 
represent women and men. 
 
b.  Human Resource Planning and Management Capacity Strengthening 
 
39.  The Project will help strengthen MOH capacity for human resource policy, planning, and 
management  through  a  range  of  interventions.  Functional  analysis  is  the  first  step  in 
rationalizing staff deployment and addressing critical staff needs in rural and remote areas, and 
will be supported in the first year of the Project. TA will be provided for MOH to use the findings 
to  develop  a  rational  human  resources  policy,  and  prepare  the  second  health  workforce 
development plan. The Project will support specific strategies to solve staff and skill shortages 
in very remote areas, including the development of a primary nurse training course for the 
northeastern provinces, with scholarships for participants from communities without adequate 
health services. The Project will also help the Government review and improve the incentive 
structure for health providers working in rural and remote areas.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits 
64.  Investments proposed under the Project will provide significant benefits to people and 
institutions. The Project will improve the coverage and quality of the health system, not only 
directly  improving  the  welfare  of  the  beneficiaries,  but  also  contributing  to  prospects  for 
economic growth, human capital of the poor, and poverty reduction. Poverty and health are 
closely interrelated, as poverty can lead to health problems while illness often leads families into 
poverty. The Project will strengthen policymaking and governance in the health sector at a 
critical time as Cambodia accelerates decentralization. The Project will serve as a springboard 
to  strengthen  coordination  and  MOH's  capacity  to  lead  and  institute  reforms  for  efficient, 
sustainable, and equitable health services.

15 
65.  Improved Coverage. The ADB-administered part of the Project will cover more than 5 
million people (40% of the total population), who will benefit from the improved availability and 
quality of health services. Project interventions will improve health care coverage for the rural 
poor, who have very limited access to even the most basic health services. An estimated 4.6 
million (92%) beneficiaries will come from the rural population. The Project will improve access 
to quality health service for 2.5 million women by strengthening safe-motherhood services, 
improving antenatal care, and providing emergency obstetric facilities. The Project will also have 
a major impact on improving the health status of ethnic minorities in the provinces of Mondol Kiri 
and Rattanak Kiri, which are among the poorest in the country. The Project includes measures 
designed to bridge the linguistic and cultural gaps that often hinder ethnic minorities’ access to 
the health system. By helping expand and strengthen MPA and CPA, the Project will ensure 
that health centers and referral hospitals have the capacity to provide primary and preventative 
health care services. The use of contracting in remote and poor operational districts will bring 
health services to deprived areas.  
 
66.  Poverty Reduction and Increased Equity. The ADB project provinces are among the 
poorest in the country and generally have worse health and nonmonetary indicators of poverty 
than the national average. Project investments are designed to provide more-than-proportionate 
benefits to the poor. The poor make up 36% of the project area population but capture at least 
47% of the project benefits. The Project supports the extension of services to the poor by 
constructing and renovating health facilities, improving providers' skills, and supporting community 
participation in rural and remote areas. The Project’s support to contracting of health services in 
remote  and  poorly  served  operational  districts  further  enhances  the  pro-poor  bias  of  the 
investments.  The  Project  also  benefits  the  near-poor,  who  make  up  about  40%  of  the 
population. One health shock is often sufficient to push an entire household into poverty. The 
Project will also provide a platform for instituting several pro-poor policies in MOH, including 
rationalization  of  user  charges,  pro-poor  health  sector  financing,  mainstreaming  of  poverty 
based planning and M&E. 
 
67.  Significant Economic Returns. Economic analysis of the project intervention shows 
that even at conservative assumptions, the Project will have an economic internal rate of return 
(EIRR)  of  27%  (Appendix  13).  Even  when  the  assumptions  regarding  project  gains  are 
extremely pessimistic, the EIRR does not go below 17%. Health service improvements in the 
project area provide three types of economic benefits to the population: (i) health improvements 
that lead to better productivity and learning outcomes at school, (ii) reduction in days lost due to 
sickness or health care, and (iii) savings in out-of-pocket expenditure on health care due to 
better and more efficient health services. The analysis could not take into account the first 
stream of benefits because of the difficulty in quantifying the gains in health and improvement in 
productivity. The analysis used data from BHSP to quantify the likely impact of the Project in 
reducing lost days due to sickness and health care and out-of-pocket expenditure. A more 
comprehensive analysis (including productivity gains) of economic benefits would likely yield a 
significantly higher EIRR. 
 
68.  Increased Health System Efficiency. Increased efficiency in service delivery, increased 
staff knowledge and skills, and improved quality of services will all help provide better value for 
money to health care consumers. By contracting health services, the Project will help promote 
appropriate and effective health care and improved, more efficient financing of health services. 
Support to functional analysis and the Health Workforce Development Plan (HWDP) will help 
remove inefficiencies in the deployment of health personnel. The Project will help increase the 
relevance and efficiency of the health system at provincial and district levels by building the 
capacity of managers. Managers will develop skills to better identify specific health needs in

16  
their area and to address them within the context of national policy and strategy. Increased 
capacity at the health centers and operational districts will enable gradual absorption of vertical 
disease management approaches into the integrated system with considerable cost-efficiency 
savings. 
 
69.  Strengthened  Health  Sector  Governance.  The  Project  will  help  the  Government 
improve  the  efficiency  of  resource  allocation  and  increase  cost-effectiveness  in  the  health 
sector. According to Cambodia Demographic and Health Survey 2000, health care resources 
are distributed inefficiently among Government ($2.50 per capita per annum), international 
agencies ($6.30), and private out-of-pocket expenditure ($25.90). Within the health sector, 
primary  health  care  does  not  receive  its  due  share.  The  Project  seeks  to  rectify  these 
inefficiencies. The Project is Cambodia’s first attempt at sector-wide management in the health 
sector. The preparation of the Strategic Plan is an important first step in setting overall priorities. 
Support and constant review of the Strategic Plan by all stakeholders under the Project will 
further help the process. The Project will support MOH in preparing and monitoring annual plans 
to operationalize the Strategic Plan. TA provided under the Project will enhance MOH’s capacity 
to undertake evidence-based decision making. The Project will strengthen MOH capacity to 
plan, finance and manage the provision of health services. Additional training and TA provided 
at the provincial and district levels will further improve capacity for planning and management at 
decentralized levels. The Project will also ensure better community feedback into planning and 
monitoring of health services through consumer surveys and participation of civil society.   
 
B.  Environmental and Social Measures 
  1.  Environment 
 
70.  The Project will have no significant adverse environmental effect. All large civil works 
entail rehabilitation of existing structures. The new structures are small and not likely to disturb 
the environment or natural resources. Handling and disposal of hazardous medical waste such 
as syringes and needles will be addressed in the design and operation of the health centers.  
 
  2.  Social Analysis 
 
71.  The Project does not have any adverse social impact (Appendix 14). A detailed social 
analysis was undertaken during the project preparation. The results of the analysis were fed into 
the project design to ensure that disadvantaged populations obtain the optimum benefits from 
the Project. No land acquisition or resettlement is planned under the Project. New structures will 
be built on government land already allocated for existing health facilities. Some social issues 
addressed by the project design are as follows: 
 
a.  Poverty 
 
72.  The project design specifically addresses the constraints often faced by the poor on 
seeking health care services. The Project will (i) focus on primary health care, which provides 
more-than-proportionate benefits to the poor; (ii) invest largely in rural health facilities used by 
the poor; (iii) focus on prevention and treatment of common communicable diseases, which 
mostly  afflict  the  poor;  (iv)  contract  out  health  services  in  11  relatively  poorer  operational 
districts to NGOs, a strategy that has been shown to benefit the poor; (v) help redress the staff 
gap and skills of providers working in poor areas; (vi) help establish social protection funds, 
which will directly help the poor deal with catastrophic and chronic health conditions; (vii) 
encourage participation of the poor in managing health services through support to health

17 
center  committees;  and  (viii)  mainstream  poverty  issues  into  planning,  budgeting,  and 
monitoring of health services. 
 
b.  Ethnic Minorities 
 
73.  Two project provinces, Mondol Kiri and Rattanak Kiri, are home to a significant number 
of ethnic minorities. Their health status is the most challenging among all target groups due to 
general poverty, difficulties in outreach, lack of health awareness, high illiteracy rates, and, in 
many cases, culturally insensitive health services. Therefore, the Ethnic Minorities Development 
Plan (EMDP) has been prepared in accordance with ADB guidelines and will be implemented as 
part of the Project (Appendix 15). 
 
c.  Gender 
 
74.  All project subcomponents will target women and girls, who will comprise more than 50% 
of project beneficiaries. One major project priority is safe motherhood and improving the access 
to quality reproductive health care. Since rural women perceive the opportunity cost of using 
health services as high, health services must be brought closer to them by improving service 
quality and reduced costs and by generating demand for services. The Project will aim to 
provide more-than-proportionate training opportunities to women (Appendix 15).  
 
C.  Risks 
75.  The  project  interventions  involve  almost  no  technical  risk.  The  technologies  and 
techniques  for  providing  effective  primary  health  care  are  well  understood  and  tested. 
Cambodia’s experience in the sector has been highly encouraging, demonstrating feasibility of 
implementation and sustained commitment of the Government. However, the implementation of 
a substantial and jointly financed project poses a serious challenge at the central, provincial, 
and  district  levels  to  the  Government’s  capacity  to  absorb  and  properly  utilize  available 
resources. Although it has successfully implemented BHSP, MOH still has weak implementation 
capacity, poorly motivated staff due to low salaries, and a weak financial managerial structure. 
These risks are being minimized through strong capacity-building support, largely funded by 
DFID, and provision of consulting services to support procurement and disbursement. DFID 
support under the Project for an interim strategy as well as a comprehensive solution to the 
problem of low salaries will also alleviate these risks.  
 
76.  Another  challenge  for  the  Government  will  be  the  sustainability  of  the  facilities 
constructed  and  the  services  introduced,  especially  after  the  Project  ends.  Financial 
sustainability of the investments is contingent on the continued provision of an adequate budget 
for the health sector, which the Government has been able to increase in recent years. Its ability 
to do so in the future depends on making better macroeconomic and fiscal progress. To ensure 
proper  maintenance  of  health  facilities  and  equipment,  the  Project  will  help  MOH  prepare 
maintenance plans for all health facilities. The Government has assured that it will at least 
maintain the proportion of the national budget currently allocated to the health sector and 
sufficiently increase the budget for maintenance for equipment and health facilities. 
 
77.  The  model  of  contracting  out  services  has  been  tested  in  Cambodia  and  showed 
impressive results in the pilot districts. The risks in the Project relate to both the capacity of this 
model to work on a larger scale – a province rather than an operational district, and to the 
chances that any improvements achieved will not be sustained once the externally supported 
contract  ends.  These  risks  have  been  minimized  through  intensive  consultations  with

18  
policymakers at provincial and national levels and modifying the design of the model to include 
an exit strategy. 
 
78.  With  elections  in  Cambodia  scheduled  for  July  2003,  it  is  likely  that  there  will  be 
distraction of efforts at senior levels and limited scope for difficult reforms. However, the Project 
has been designed to use this period to plan and lay foundations for future implementation and 
most support in this period will be in the form of TA. This will minimize the risk of diversion of 
resources or lack of decision-making. 
 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
79.  The Government and MOH have given the following assurances, in addition to the 
standard assurances, which have been incorporated in the legal documents: 
 
A.  Specific Assurances 
 
(i)  The Government and MOH will ensure that no later than 30 April 2003 and in each year 
thereafter, an annual review of the health sector is organized. Documents to be prepared 
as the basis for the review will be circulated to ADB, DFID, and IDA no later than 2 
weeks  before  the  scheduled  review  and  should  include  (a)  a  review  of  sector 
performance (summarizing sector performance indicators and trends, implementation 
progress of agreed-upon policy measures, and institutional reforms); (b) a review of past 
progress and future plans to implement the health sector institutional capacity-building 
plan and the health infrastructure development plan; (c) a procurement audit and details 
of government budget and actual expenditure in the previous year; and (d) a draft 3-year 
rolling plan for health sector development, comprising a detailed description of activities, 
costs, and sources of funds for the first year. No later than 15 October 2003 and in each 
subsequent year, MOH will submit for review and comments to ADB, DFID, and IDA the 
final version of the annual operational plan approved by MEF. 
 
(ii)  The Government and MOH will ensure that no later than 31 May 2003 and in each year 
thereafter, they will provide to ADB, DFID, and IDA an annual operational plan for the 
health sector for the upcoming year. No later than 31 July of each year, the Government 
and  MOH  will  finalize  and  approve  the  3-year  rolling  plan,  including  the  annual 
operational plan, incorporating the suggestions of ADB, DFID, and IDA. 
(iii)  MOH will submit by 30 April 2004 for review and concurrence of ADB, DFID, and IDA 
during  the  2004  annual  review,  a  plan  to  strengthen  the  administration  of  health 
services. The MOH health sector institutional capacity-building plan will include a review 
of current and future responsibilities, revised organizational charts, proposed numbers 
and profiles of key staff, and a training plan to develop capabilities. The Government will 
ensure that the plan will be implemented in 2004-2007.  
(iv)  MOH will submit by 30 April 2004 for review and concurrence of ADB, DFID, and IDA 
during  the  2004  annual  review,  a  health  infrastructure  development  plan  and  a 
maintenance plan. The health infrastructure development plan will indicate the type of 
health facilities proposed to be developed, their locations, the nature of civil works to be 
carried out, and implications for staffing of the proposed facilities. The maintenance plan 
will cover buildings, equipment, and vehicles. The Government will ensure that these 
plans are implemented in 2004-2007.

during the 2004 annual review, (a) a review of the HWDP (1996-2005) and (b) the 
proposed HWDP for 2005-2013.  HWDP 2005-2013 should take into account the MPA 
and CPA guidelines and the infrastructure development plan. It will propose specific 
measures to deploy, manage, and train health providers. It will also identify measures to 
establish a sector-wide solution for the problem of low salaries for health providers.

health sector will have been disbursed by 30 September of each year from FY2003.  
(viii)  The Government and MOH will ensure (a) starting in 2003, allocation of at least 60% of 
the new recurrent spending above the previous fiscal year for provincial and district 
hospitals and commune health centers, and for programs that directly target the poor; (b) 
by 30 April 2004, review of exemptions made in various cost-recovery arrangements in 
the sector, and propose mechanisms to benefit the poor during the 2004 annual review; 
(c) by September 2006, evaluation of various initiatives to help the poor afford health 
care, including a social protection fund pilot and, if effective and feasible, mainstreaming 
of such schemes in the Government strategy; and (d) allocation of the health sector 
budget to provinces and districts, and development and subsequent implementation of a 
formula that incorporates, among other things, poverty criteria and disease burden.  
(ix)  The Government and MOH will ensure that for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2007, 
budgetary allocation to health education and consumer behavior programs increases by 
at least 10%.  
(x)  The Government and MOH will ensure that (a) contracted districts receive an MOH 
operating budget at levels comparable to those of noncontracted districts. Operating 
budget to the contracted districts will be disbursed in lumpsum by MOH DBF to the

that the ethnic minorities have equal opportunities to participate in training, recruitment, 
and promotion of health workers.

prepared during the appraisal. They will further ensure that in selecting the participants 
for all training activities, priority will be given to achieving at least the same proportion of 
women trainees as in the overall pool of the targeted staff, with the ultimate goal of 
reaching gender equality in the training, recruitment, and promotion of health workers. 
(xiii)  Although  no  significant  environmental  impacts  were  identified,  the  siting,  design, 
construction, rehabilitation, and operation of the health centers and referral hospitals will 
be implemented in line with ADB’s environmental guidelines. Handling and disposal 
measures for hazardous medical waste will be carried out strictly in accordance with the 
prescribed design and operation of the health centers.

SUMMARY OF THE CAMBODIA HEALTH SECTOR STRATEGIC PLAN 2003–2007 
 
1.  The Ministry of Health (MOH) recently developed its first Strategic Plan, articulating 
goals, desired health outcomes, priority areas for intervention, and intervention strategies for 
2003-2007. The Strategic Plan was launched by the Prime Minister on 22 August 2002. MOH’s 
5-year strategic goal is to “enhance health sector development in order to improve the health of 
the  people  of  Cambodia,  especially  mothers  and  children,  thereby  contributing  to  poverty 
alleviation and socioeconomic development.” Goals include reductions in the high infant, child, 
and maternal mortality rates. 
 
2.  Key Constraints. The plan identifies and seeks to address the following: 
 
(i)  low salaries of health staff in the public sector and lack of incentives to work in 
remote areas. While broader public administrative reforms are underway, interim 
strategies  are  needed  to  improve  the  income  of  government  health  staff  to 
achieve the plan's objectives; 
(ii)  irregular and inadequate flow of government funds. Although the national health 
budget has increased, access to funds, and, therefore, expenditures, remains 
low; 
(iii)  high prices, which limit access to services, particularly hospital services, by the 
poor; 
(iv)  poor quality of care in public and private sectors; 
(v)  poor attitudes and practices among service providers in communicating with 
consumers; 
(vi)  maldistribution of health service providers, especially trained midwives; 
(vii)  inadequate  managerial  capacities  for  monitoring,  evaluation,  supervision, 
delegation, and evidence-based decision making; and 
(viii)  limited coordination of external financing in the sector. 
 
3.  Priority Interventions. The Strategic Plan identifies the following priority interventions: 
 
(i)  health service delivery: improving coverage and utilization through improvements 
in the public health system and collaboration with the private sector;  
(ii)  improvement of the weak interpersonal skills of health care providers and their 
responsiveness to consumer needs, especially of the poor; 
(iii)  improvement of the quality of public and private sector services;  
(iv)  human  resource  development  in  terms  of  skills  and  effective  deployment  of 
personnel; 
(v)  improved health financing in the context of a sector that is underfunded and 
suffers from poor access to agreed allocations; and 
(vi)  institutional development to enable MOH to implement these interventions and 
associated strategies. 
 
4.  The highest priority intervention is improved health service delivery and coverage, since 
they will directly reduce morbidity and mortality. The five other priorities are necessary to 
achieve the first, since without changes in the health sector as a whole and MOH as an 
institution, the chances of achieving the intended outcomes are limited. 
 
5.  Key strategies to be employed in these intervention areas include 
(i)  improving  coverage  and  access  to  health  services,  especially  for  the  poor, 
through appropriate location of health facilities;

ANNUAL HEALTH SECTOR REVIEW PROCESS 
1.  An annual health sector review will be established to assess sectoral progress. The 
Project will help organize these sector reviews. The annual health sector review process will 
bring together stakeholders active in the health sector to review progress on agreed-upon key 
issues, against a core indicator set and agreed-upon annual milestones.  The establishment of 
baselines will be a priority in 2003. The project cofinanciers and other development partners 
have a broad consensus on a joint review process. The review will reduce the need for time-
consuming and costly individual progress reviews by each development partner and improve 
the sharing of information between stakeholders. 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
2.  The objectives of the joint annual health sector review process are the following:  
  
(i)  review the progress in delivering the Health Sector Strategic Plan; 
(ii)  develop a mechanism for joint review and collaboration under the coordination of 
the Ministry of Health (MOH); 
(iii)  provide an opportunity for policy dialogue and joint consideration of key issues 
and constraints, including issues of equity and sustainability; 
(iv)  identify and agree on main priorities and a limited number of milestones for 
FY2004 and subsequent years; and 
(v)  discuss  the  comprehensive  3-year  rolling  plan  integrating  the  proposed 
contributions of all stakeholders, and adopt the annual plan comprising planned 
activities and sources of financing for the coming year.  
 
B.  Outline of the Process 
 
3.  The annual review will consist of the following activities:  
 
(i)  an annual technical review that will assess progress and key issues relating to 
the seven priority strategic areas as outlined in Strategic Plan, and led by the 
Government, with appropriate technical assistance (TA); and 
(ii)  policy and planning review meetings, twice a year.  
 
4.  The annual review will provide information to the annual budget and planning cycle. The 
timing of the technical review and the policy and planning review meetings will need to be 
carefully considered to fit in with the Government budgetary and planning cycle to ensure full 
value is made of the findings and recommendations.  The report of the findings of the technical 
review will be made available in advance of the first policy and planning review.  The technical 
review will be conducted around March every year to allow annual reporting of progress for the 
previous financial year and policy and planning reviews around June and November, in line with 
the budget and planning timetable.  An initial consultative exercise could be undertaken to set 
the first milestones based on a review of baseline data and work plans.  
 
C.  Annual Technical Review  
 
5.  To allow an informed judgment on progress in the sector and project, a number of 
requirements  for  the  annual  health  sector  review  linked  to  planning,  management,  and 
implementation need to be agreed upon.  These should be in the form of a set of milestones to 
be achieved by specified times.

6.  Examples of annual milestones (to be achieved before the technical review) are the 
following:  
 
(i)  public expenditure review for the health sector; 
(ii)  annual  health  sector  profile  (report  based  on  the  core  indicator  set  that 
demonstrates overall progress in the sector against established baselines); 
(iii)  annual independent review of procurement;  
(iv)  annual workforce plan and annual report (including salary review); and

7.  Many  stakeholders  are  involved  in  the  Health  Sector  Support  Plan  2003–2007.

2.  A comparable operating budget supplement was made available to the control areas. 
Intervention and control areas consisted of an entire district, each with a population of 100,000–
200,000. There were 4 control, 3 CI, and 2 CO districts. 
  
3.  Evaluation  indicators  were  established  and  baseline  household  and  health  facility 
surveys  conducted  before  the  intervention.  An  independent  evaluation,  including  repeat 
household and health facility surveys, was conducted in mid-2001, 2.5 years after contractors 
commenced  work.  All  districts  at  baseline  had  less  than  20%  of  planned  health  facilities 
functional and extremely poor health service coverage. The CI, CO, and control groups had 
similar socioeconomic status and baseline health service coverage. 
 
B.  Results 
1.  Was Contracting Effective? 
4.  Results  of  the  final  survey  show  that  contracted  districts  consistently  outperformed 
control districts with respect to the predefined coverage indicators. The CO model was more 
highly performing than the CI model. Table A6.1 summarizes the changes in 11 health service 
coverage indicators over 2.5 years. 
 
5.  Starting with comparable levels, CO districts increased health service utilization to 1.7 
per contact per capita per annum, and CI districts to 1.2. Control districts had an annual per 
capita  contact  rate  of  only  0.8.  CO  districts  witnessed  an  impressive  increase  in  use  of 
reproductive health services. For example, coverage of antenatal care increased by more than

Appendix 6  35 
400%, but only by 233% in CI districts and 160% in control districts. Success in the coverage of 
child  health  services  also  followed  a  similar  pattern.  Immunization  rates  increased  in  CO 
districts by 158%, in CI districts by 82%, and in control districts by 56%. 
 
2.  Was Contracting Efficient?  
6.  The final survey measured the productive time lost due to illness by patients and their 
caretakers. The results showed that on an average, people in CO districts lost about 15% less 
time on illness and seeking health care compared to control districts. People in CI districts lost 
about 5% less time due to illness compared to control districts. Comparable data were not 
available  in  the  baseline  survey  to  assess  changes  in  lost  time  over  the  contract  period. 
However, contracted districts had higher utilization of services and still had lower time lost due 
to sickness and health care. This implies that in contracted districts primary health care was 
more accessible, obviating the need to travel long distances to seek care. These districts also 
had more efficient and early diagnosis and more rational treatment, which may have reduced 
the need for hospitalization and shortened the illnesses. 
 
7.  The pilot measured cost-effectiveness of contracting with respect to the delivery of 
predefined health services. While service was more expensive in the contracting than in the 
control districts, it turned out to be more cost-effective when health service outcomes were 
factored in the evaluation (Table A6.2). A dollar invested through CO yielded about 50% better 
outcomes than in the control districts. Contracting of services appears to be more sustainable 
as well since it had lower recurrent cost, taking into account private expenditures (Table A6.3). 
 
3.  Was Contracting Equitable? 
8.  The evaluation shows that contracted districts not only achieved better health care 
utilization and significant efficiencies, but also provided more than proportionate benefits to the 
poor. Much of the increase in health care utilization in contracted districts was attributable to the 
increased use of services by households of low socioeconomic status. For example, use of 
curative health services at district hospitals by the bottom-half socioeconomic group increased 
by 1,096% in CO districts and by 491% in CI districts in 2.5 years. The corresponding increase 
in the control districts was considerably lower at 82%. 
 
9.  While the use of services by the households of low socioeconomic status increased in 
contracted districts, their actual out-of-pocket-payment for health care utilization, even when 
user fees were charged by contractors, substantially decreased. Private out-of-pocket health 
care expenditures by the bottom-half socioeconomic group reduced by up to 70% during the 
contract period. The reduction in out-of-pocket costs was greater among this population than the 
overall  population,  indicating  successful  targeting  of  the  desired  beneficiaries  and  efficient 
transfer of subsidies. The out-of-pocket expenditure for the bottom-half socioeconomic group 
was reduced by $35 per capita, which compares extremely favorably to about $4 per capita per 
year invested through contracting of services. Clearly, this was achieved through reduction in 
use of inefficient services and reduction in travel expenditure by providing services closer to 
home. Control districts showed an increase in private expenditures  (Table A6.4).

1.  This appendix summarizes the analysis of the economic contribution of the Project to the 
health system and the overall sustainability of the health sector and the effect of the Project on 
the Government’s long-term fiscal position (Supplementary Appendix H).    
 
A.  Economic Rationale of the Project 
2.  The economic rationale for investing in health in Cambodia is strong, particularly for 
introducing primary health care. The Project will support the implementation of the Minimum 
Package of Activities (MPA) and the Complementary Package of Activities (CPA), which are 
designed to ensure that the population, particularly the poor, has access to basic, cost-efficient 
health services. Included in the MPA are basic interventions such as immunization, antenatal 
care,  birth-spacing  services,  basic  nutrition  interventions,  and  prevention  and  treatment  of 
common  diseases  such  as  tuberculosis  and  malaria.  These  interventions  generate  large 
externalities and can be provided at low cost.  
 
3.  Health care is characterized by asymmetrical information on medical interventions; the 
health care provider typically knows more about the need and efficacy of treatment than the 
receiver, especially in Cambodia, where the education level of patients is low and consumers 
are often ignorant about even basic health practices. Publicly provided health services can help 
bridge the gap and provide information about good health practices and alternatives in health 
care.  Credit  markets  are  weak  in  Cambodia  and  health  insurance  is  nonexistent.  Proper 
adherence to a formal fee system for health care will reduce uncertainty about health care 
expenditures. Schemes should be established to protect the poor from the burden of health care 
cost.  
 
4.  The Project will also support training of health workers, particularly health workers in 
remote areas. While training does provide private benefits, in Cambodia these are likely to be 
small compared to the public benefits of having better-trained health workers in a remote area. 
Since  the  public  sector  health  care  providers  work  in  the  public  and  private  sectors  and 
constitute most human resources in health, improved skills of health care providers will benefit 
the entire health sector.

C.   Financial Sustainability of the Health Sector 
16.  The sustainability of the health care system is of serious concern to the Government. 
Cambodia is still reconstructing its economy and health care system and, as a result, resources 
available for all sectors (including health) are limited. Although the health needs of the country 
are great, any investment in the health system must be sustainable with domestic resources. 
 
17.  Cambodia is unusual among Asian countries, with its large share of health spending—an 
estimated 12% of Gross Domestic Product (GDP). Of this, the largest percentage comes from 
household  expenditures,  at  83%.  The  Government’s  contribution  to  total  health  care  is 
estimated to be 5%, and that of development partners, the remaining 12%. The Government’s 
effort is severely limited by its narrow revenue base, accounting for around 12% of GDP.   
   
18.  While the private sector can be an important source of quality in the health sector, most 
studies in Cambodia suggest that the country’s over-reliance on the private sector has serious 
consequences on efficiency due to the lack of supervision and regulation. The private sector 
providers rely heavily on the prescription of inappropriate and poor-quality drugs. Serious equity 
issues also exist, associated with high private costs and a weak social safety net. Health has a 
strong public-good component that requires government support. 
 
19.  The  health  sector  is  largely  dependent  on  international  support  and  consumers  for 
financing. Consumers often have limited information about their health care options. A good 
deal of international resources go to capacity building and capital expenditures, which do not 
directly contribute to basic health care. Estimates are that a basic package of publicly provided 
services should cost $12–24 per capita per year.  
 
20.  The Government does not have the resources to sustain the health sector on its own. 
With a budget of $2–3 per capita, Government spending is well below the recommended targets 
for health spending. Given Cambodia’s low income and small revenue base, the country will 
have to depend on international assistance for a few more years. Cambodia needs to develop a 
strategy to ensure that the health sector can continue to function with reduced international 
support, and a strategy to better target private health care spending to improve the sector’s 
efficiency.  
 
21.  Primary health care is funded by the Government, user fees, and funding agencies. 
Fiscal sustainability analysis assumes the following:

(ii)   The Government’s share in the economy will grow moderately following targets

Cambodia  already  spends  substantially  more  than  $12  per  capita  on  health  care,  largely

Cambodia would already be well above the recommended level. With the long-term increase in 
education and with improvements in the health care system, household spending will have a 
more positive impact on health.  
 
D.  Financial Sustainability of the Project 
 
23.  As discussed in the section on economic costs and benefits, the Project will impact on 
the Government’s health spending in several different areas. Contracting of health services 
requires that the Government take over the cost of the contract in the long run. The construction 
of  new  civil  works  and  the  provision  of  equipment  will  require  additional  spending  on 
maintenance. While these costs are modest, they will require real commitment on the part of the 
Government to ensure that the benefits of the investment are not lost.  
 
24.  The Project is part of a larger health sector reform program, with additional funding from 
Department for International Development (DFID) and IDA. It is estimated that the ADB and

necessary for the health sector, following current trends, Cambodia is in a good position to 
sustain the proposed investment.

(iv)  The use of contracting in the remote provinces of Mondol Kiri and Rattanak Kiri 
will lead to significant improvements in access to health in areas with little or no 
formal health care (component 1.4.2).  
(v)  Increased community participation in the health system will ensure that basic 
health services are responsive to local needs and are culturally appropriate. The 
project will support the establishment of health center community committees 
(component 3.1).  
 
8.  The  ethnic  minority  strategy  focuses  on  designing  interventions  that  are  culturally 
appropriate and will improve the access of ethnic minorities to basic health services:  
 
(i)  Training community-based health workers from Mondol Kiri and Rattanak Kiri will 
ensure that the staff that serve the ethnic minority population speak the local 
language and are familiar with the local culture The training program will be 
designed to take into account the low initial level of education of ethnic minority 
students (component 3.2.5).  
(ii)  The construction of small, village-based health posts will provide basic services 
to low-density populations. The health posts also permit the local population to 
staff health services rather than rely on outsiders to staff larger health centers 
(component 1.1).  
(iii)  The development of guidelines for nongovernment organization (NGO) selection 
for contracting in Mondol Kiri and Rattanak Kiri will ensure that the NGO will train 
and employ local staff familiar with the ethnic minority languages and cultures 
(component 1.4.2). 
(iv)  The introduction of a formal national and provincial affirmative action plan will 
ensure that ethnic minorities help manage the health system (components 3.1.1, 
3.2.1, and 3.2.2).  
(v)  Community  participation  in  the  management  of  local  health  services  will  be 
ensured. For cultural and linguistic reasons, the participation strategy may need 
to be modified to ensure that ethnic minorities (and particularly hill tribes) have an 
adequate voice in the health system. The contracted NGOs in Mondol Kiri and 
Rattanak Kiri will develop a culturally sensitive participation strategy for their 
contracted district.  
(vi)  An ethnic minority-disaggregated monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system will be 
institutionalized in Ministry of Health (MOH) (component 3.3) 
 
9.  Developing the capacity of the Government to monitor the implementation of EMDP is 
essential. As part of the EMDP, the following steps will be undertaken:

(i)  A focal point for ethnic minority issues will be designated by the provincial health 
services in Mondol Kiri, Rattanak Kiri, and, if necessary, in other provinces. The 
focal point will serve as a liaison among the provincial health service, contracted 
NGOs, MOH, and the local population.  
(ii)  All annual reviews will ensure that the terms of EMDP are met and will discuss 
their  progress.  ADB  will  program  a  special  review  mission  to  focus  on  the 
concerns of ethnic minorities in the third or fourth year of the project.  
(iii)  The Project will request that ethnic minority-specific questions be included in 
future health and living standard surveys to ensure that it is possible to track the 
health status of ethnic minorities. ADB will ensure that M&E activities under the 
Project  incorporate  the  concerns  of  ethnic  minorities.  Monitoring  will  be 
qualitative and quantitative.  
 
B.  Gender Strategy 
 
10.  Women in Cambodia are disproportionately burdened by health problems. Although the 
Strategic Plan focuses on ensuring that the health system will equally benefit men and women, 
specific actions and investments are needed to realize this intention. The gender strategy is the 
Project's contribution to the commitment of the Government and ADB to improve the health 
status of women and ensure their full participation in the health system. 
 
11.  The Project is classified as a gender intervention because of the significant benefits 
that  women  will  receive.  The  Project  is  built  around  the  Strategic  Plan,  and  stresses  the 
availability of sufficient resources for Minimum Package of Activity (MPA) and Complementary 
Package of Activity (CPA), which emphasize women's health, particularly reproductive health. 
Given  the  limited  resources  available  for  health  in  Cambodia,  the  Project  recognizes  that 
investing in reproductive health will have a positive impact on the welfare of the population. 
 
12.  Following the Government and ADB strategy, the Project is committed to mainstreaming 
gender concerns. It will support many interventions and reforms that will benefit both women 
and men, including efforts to increase the affordability and access to health services. In addition, 
the  Project  will  introduce  a  number  of  changes  that  will  target  women  specifically.  The 
implementation of the MPA will significantly increase access to reproductive health for 1.2 
million women of reproductive age. At least 5,200 female health workers will be trained in the 
MPA and CPA to ensure that more women can be attended to. Many partners are providing 
significant support (including through this Project) to the national HIV/AIDS strategy that will also 
benefit women, who are disproportionately burdened by HIV/AIDS.  
 
13.  Key to implementing the gender strategy is ensuring that the health system serves the 
health needs of men and women. The formal health system has health center community 
committees (HCCCs) to involve the community in the management of health centers. The 
HCCC consists of one man and one woman per village covered by the health center. Many 
areas, however, do not have an active HCCC. The Project will help communities establish 
HCCCs where none exist.  
 
14.  Ensuring Women Benefit Proportionately from the Project. The underlying principle 
of the Project is that women's health concerns should be mainstreamed in the health sector 
through a gender mainstreaming strategy. It will attempt to ensure that the health system takes 
into account the cultural and biological differences between men and women. The Project will 
also have a gender targeting strategy to ensure that women receive adequate support from the 
health  system.  The  Project  will  monitor  the  implementation  of  the  gender  mainstreaming

strategy.  
 
15.  It will be implemented through the following as part of the Project:  
 
(i)  To  ensure  that  women  are  adequately  represented  in  the  health  system,  a 
significant number of women health workers will be trained under the project. 
Equal opportunity for women to receive training is essential and the Project will 
ensure that women will receive training at least in proportion to their numbers in 
the health system, with the ultimate goal of at least 40% of trainees being women 
in 2007 (component 1.3).  
(ii)  The Project will ensure that civil works provide adequate visual and auditory 
privacy for patients, which is particularly important for women (component 1.1).  
(iii)  The Project will help establish health center feedback committees (HCFCs) in 
communes  where  the  committees  are  not  operating.  HCFCs  provide  equal 
representation to men and women and ensure that their voices are heard in the 
management of local health centers (component 3.1).  
(iv)  Ethnic minority women are often especially disadvantaged due to their low formal 
education and contact with the formal health system. The Project will focus on 
training  ethnic  minority  women  health  workers,  who  have  the  cultural  and 
linguistic knowledge to treat ethnic minority women effectively. More than 50% of 
the trainees in remote provinces will be women (components 1.3 and 3.2).  
 
16.  The gender targeting strategy will be built into the Project and will serve to improve the 
health status of women. In particular the Project will work to accomplish the following:  
 
(i)  Incorporate  the  MPA  and  CPA  in  the  health  system,  which  will  significantly 
improve  women's  access  to  reproductive  health  services  and  benefit 
approximately 1.2 million women living in project operating districts (components 
1.2 and 1.3).  
(ii)  Improve  the  relevance  of  messages  that  encourage  women’s  health-seeking 
behavior, for themselves and for children (component 3.2).  
(iii)  Institutionalize a gender-disaggregated M&E system (component 3.3) 
 
17.  ADB  will  work  with  the  Government  and  other  partners  to  ensure  that  the  gender 
strategy is implemented. The Project will ensure the strategy’s implementation. Annual reviews 
to be conducted jointly with all partners will ensure that the terms of the strategy are met, and a 
discussion on its progress will be included in progress reports.
